Bott = Planck = sheared Rees

Aug 2, 2020

In this post (and presumably the following few, too, because I expect this to get quite long), I would like to talk about an idea that over the past six months has come to become a tenet of the way I think about quantum mechanics, Hodge theory, -actions, filtrations, etc. The core idea is expressed in the following equation:

Here, (denoted equivalently by ) is the degree Bott element in (where is a complex oriented ring spectrum); is the Planck constant; and is the parameter in “-connections” that encodes the order filtration on D-modules (or more generally the parameter appearing in the Rees construction of a filtered module), i.e., the Hodge filtration.

Here’s the plan for this post (these posts?). I’m going to try to give an exposition of (perturbative) quantum mechanics/field theory as motivation for deformation quantization; use that to say a bit about deformation quantization of symplectic manifolds from the modern point of view, as pioneered by Kontsevich; talk about how this is analogous to the degeneration of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence; briefly go over nonabelian Hodge theory (again!); then go back to the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence and state what it’s got to do with Hochschild homology and circle actions, where we’ll see that the Bott element corresponds to the deformation parameter/”the Planck constant”. Then, we will use our equation relating , , and to discuss deformation quantization in characteristic from the more homotopically-flavored point of view; we’ll see that quantized algebras (following Bezrukavnikov-Kaledin) essentially come from -actions, and that restricted structures on quantized algebras can be viewed as the Dyer-Lashof operation . (In fact, we will see that cyclotomic spectra are the homotopical analogues of Frobenius-constant quantizations.) I haven’t tried to prove something like the Azumaya algebra property from Proposition 1.24 (see also Lemma 3.2) of their paper, but it should certainly be doable (although, as far as I understand, their techniques don’t really generalize to the homotopical setting).

We will start off in characteristic zero, and will switch over to characteristic later; in fact, until mentioned otherwise, you should just assume that the base field is .

Part one: /deformation quantization

Let’s begin with a review of quantum theory; there’s a lot to say here, so I will say only the minimal amount necessary to get to the math. It’s not really crucial to understand the physics if you’re willing to forego the motivation; if you don’t want to read the physics motivation, just skip down to where we start talking about Poisson brackets.

There are at least two approaches to time evolution in quantum mechanics: in the Schrodinger picture, the states evolve through time (as described by the Schrodinger equation), while the operators (like the Hamiltonian) remains constant; in the Heisenbeg picture, the states remain constant, while the operators evolve through time. In the Schrodinger picture, the equation of motion can be solved to give , where is a time evolution operator (which is , if the Hamiltonian is time-independent). In the Heisenberg picture, the state remains constant, while an operator evolves as . Using the Schrodinger equation, one can show that the the equation of motion in the Heisenberg picture is

(If has no time dependence, then the final term vanishes.) The upshot is that the dynamical variables in the Schrodinger picture are the states, while the dynamical variables in the Heisenberg picture are the operators.

Now, given a classical system, one can try to construct a corresponding quantum theory. There are many ways of doing so: for example, the Lagrangian formalism in classical mechanics can be quantized via the path integral formalism (which is the easiest to do calculations with, at least perturbatively, and which is equivalent to the Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures); the Hamiltonian formalism in classical mechanics can be approached canonical quantization, where it can be studied via the Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures. In canonical quantization, one promotes classical dynamical variables like position and momentum to operators. Geometric quantization (which I don’t understand) seems to focus on quantization via the Schrodinger picture, while deformation quantization focuses on the Heisenberg picture.

To motivate how deformation quantization focuses on the Heisenberg picture, recall that Hamilton’s equation of motion in classical mechanics states that if is a function on the phase space of our classical system (where is position, is momentum, and is time), then

Here, is the Poisson bracket (in canonical coordinates, it is ). The upshot is that, in the Heisenberg picture, the Poisson bracket is quantized to . So, if is a manifold equipped with a Poisson bracket, we might define a quantization of to be a product on (where is a formal variable) such that the commutator is given by

In the algebraic setting, if is a smooth variety with a Poisson bracket, then we can define a quantization to be a flat associative -algebra (with product denoted by ) such that , and satisfying the same commutator relation. For example, suppose is the formal affine plane , with Poisson bracket determined by the symplectic form . Then, a quantization is given by (in fact, this is the only quantization). Note that, in particular, setting takes us back to the classical world, just as one would expect from a physical point of view: at a scale when is tiny, quantum mechanical effects cease to be significant.

It is important to note that if you’re scourging the literature for perturbative expansions and you’re finding that just doesn’t appear anywhere, it’s because physicists set in quantum mechanical calculations. These are “natural units”, but, as we shall see when talking about Hodge theory, setting to has real mathematical content (even though it means having divergent formal power series expansions in quantum mechanics).

(Before I proceed, I’d just like to say that one can also observe that in the path integral approach also reduces to the classical story. Here’s a disappointing-even-to-physicists-level-of-rigor argument. If and are points, then the probability amplitude for a particle to go from to in a time is given by , where the integral is over the space of paths. Now, suppose that . Then, the contribution from two paths and do cancel each other out (constructively interfere) iff is approximately . Roughly, this means that and are close to each other, and is maximized at . So, as , there’s only one dominating contribution for the integral for the probability amplitude coming from a path which extremizes the action. By Euler-Lagrange, this is the classical trajectory of the particle. If you want to see a more precise discussion, the keyword here is “stationary phase approximation”, and essentially boils down to Taylor expanding the action around a critical point to the second order, combined with the fact that

which in turn can be proved by completing the square in the exponential and using the classical calculation of the integral of .)

Kontsevich’s theorem is that every Poisson manifold has a deformation quantization. In fact, he gave an explicit formula for the product as a perturbative expansion of a path integral via Feynman diagrams.

We won’t need to know the proof (because we’ll soon be talking about a different formality statement), but it is a great result, so we’ll sketch it anyway. A proof of Kontsevich’s theorem goes by reducing to showing that the Hochschild cochains are a formal dg-Lie algebra. Indeed, if is a smooth variety/manifold, then the HKR theorem says that the Hochschild cohomology of is quasi-isomorphic to the dg-algebra of polyvector fields on (i.e., ) with zero differential. The deformations of are controlled by the dg-Lie algebra given by the Hochschild homology with the Gerstenhaber bracket; namely, deformations of are classified by solutions to the Maurer-Cartan equation in this dg-Lie algebra. On the other hand, solutions to the Maurer-Cartan equation in with the usual Lie bracket are in bijection with Poisson structures on : if , then the Poisson bracket is given by . So, if the HKR quasi-isomorphism could be upgraded to a quasi-isomorphism of dg-Lie algebras, then we’d see that every Poisson structure on gives rise to a deformation of . (There’s an issue here, namely that the quasi-isomorphism of the HKR theorem doesn’t actually respect the bracket, but it can be corrected to one, in the sense that the first “Taylor coefficient” of the correction is the HKR map; see 4.6.2 here. These correction terms are where the path integral stuff comes from.)

By the Deligne conjecture, the Hochschild cochains admit the structure of an -algebra, and one can then formally reduce (ha) the desired formality statement (see here) to showing that the -operad is formal in characteristic zero. This was proved by Kontsevich (for the -operad in characteristic zero in general). As a remark, the homology of the -operad in characteristic zero encodes the structure of a Gerstenhaber algebra (where the Gerstenhaber bracket is given by the Browder bracket).

In the next post, we will talk about Hodge theory.
